title: WSL - Windows Subsystem for Linux
text:
Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) allows you to run a Linux environment directly on Windows without the need for a traditional virtual machine or dual-boot setup.






Restart and enter BIOS/UEFI (press F2, F10, F12, Del, or Esc during boot)
Navigate to CPU/Processor settings
Enable Intel VT-x (Intel) or AMD-V (AMD)
Save and Exit (usually F10)







Tip



Verify: Open Task Manager â†’ Performance â†’ CPU â†’ Check â€œVirtualizationâ€ is Enabled





Option A - GUI:
- Press Win + R â†’ Type optionalfeatures â†’ Enable:
- âœ… Virtual Machine Platform
- âœ… Windows Hypervisor Platform
- âœ… Windows Subsystem for Linux
- Restart when prompted
Option B - PowerShell (Admin):
dism.exe /online /enable-feature /featurename:Microsoft-Windows-Subsystem-Linux /all /norestart
dism.exe /online /enable-feature /featurename:VirtualMachinePlatform /all /norestart
dism.exe /online /enable-feature /featurename:HypervisorPlatform /all /norestart
Restart-Computer







wsl --set-default-version 2



wsl --list --online



# Install default Ubuntu
wsl --install -d Ubuntu

# Or specific version
wsl --install -d Ubuntu-22.04






Note



On first launch, create a UNIX username and password (needed for sudo commands)





wsl --list --verbose







# View installed distributions
wsl --list --verbose

# Unregister/uninstall (deletes all data!)
wsl --unregister <DistroName>



# Launch WSL
wsl

# Shutdown all distributions
wsl --shutdown

# Terminate specific distribution
wsl --terminate <DistroName>

# Update WSL
wsl --update






Tip



Access Linux files from Windows: Type \\wsl$ in File Explorer
Access Windows from Linux: Windows drives are at /mnt/c/, /mnt/d/, etc.









Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) is a compatibility layer developed by Microsoft that enables users to run a Linux environment directly on Windows without the overhead of a traditional virtual machine or dual-boot configuration.



Native Linux binaries run directly on Windows
Seamless integration between Windows and Linux filesystems
Low resource overhead compared to traditional VMs
Full Linux kernel (in WSL 2) for complete system call compatibility
Multiple distributions can be installed simultaneously

WSL 2




Architecture
Translation layer
Full Linux kernel

Partial

Good
Excellent

Excellent

Fast
Very Fast


Memory Usage
Lower
Higher (but managed)


Docker Support
Limited
Full



Recommendation: Use WSL 2 for most use cases, especially for development work.





A hypervisor (also called a Virtual Machine Monitor or VMM) is software, firmware, or hardware that creates and manages virtual machines (VMs). It allows multiple operating systems to share a single hardware host by abstracting the physical hardware.



Resource Allocation - Distributes CPU, memory, storage, and network resources to VMs
Isolation - Ensures VMs are isolated from each other for security and stability
Hardware Abstraction - Presents virtual hardware to guest operating systems
Management - Controls VM lifecycle (creation, execution, termination)








Runs directly on the hostâ€™s hardware without an underlying operating system.
Characteristics:
- âœ… Better performance (direct hardware access)
- âœ… Lower latency
- âœ… More secure (smaller attack surface)
- âœ… Used in enterprise/production environments
Examples: - VMware ESXi
- Microsoft Hyper-V (when installed as a server role)
- Xen
- KVM (Kernel-based Virtual Machine)
- Proxmox VE
Use Cases:
- Data centers
- Cloud infrastructure (AWS, Azure, Google Cloud)
- Enterprise server virtualization

WSL 2 bridges both worlds: - Uses virtualization (lightweight VM) - Supports containerization (Docker Desktop) - Provides the best of both approaches




Modern CPUs include hardware support for virtualization:



Hardware-assisted virtualization for Intel processors

Enables efficient VM execution

Required for WSL 2, Hyper-V, and most modern hypervisors





AMDâ€™s equivalent to Intel VT-x

Why Hardware Virtualization Matters:
- ğŸš€ Performance - VMs run at near-native speed

A virtualization technique where the guest OS is aware itâ€™s running in a virtual environment and cooperates with the hypervisor for better performance.
Examples: Xen (paravirtualization mode), VMware Guest Tools



The guest OS is unaware itâ€™s virtualized. The hypervisor emulates complete hardware.
Examples: VMware, VirtualBox, KVM with hardware extensions



Running a hypervisor inside a virtual machine (VM within a VM).
Use Cases: - Testing hypervisor software - Cloud development environments - Training and education






WSL 2 provides a powerful, efficient way to run Linux on Windows by leveraging:

âœ… Hyper-V hypervisor for lightweight virtualization
âœ… Hardware virtualization (Intel VT-x / AMD-V) for performance
âœ… Full Linux kernel for complete compatibility
âœ… Seamless integration with Windows for productivity

This makes it an ideal solution for developers who need Linux tools while working primarily on Windows.

- Install development tools (git, python, node, etc.)
- Set up Docker Desktop with WSL 2 backend
- Configure your favorite terminal (Windows Terminal recommended)
- Install VS Code with WSL extension for seamless development

UV is a fast Python package installer and resolver written in Rust.


Use Official Link: https://docs.astral.sh/uv/
# Install UV using the official installer
curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh

# Verify installation
uv --version



# Old Venv style, in my-project1 folder
uv init
source .venv/bin/activate
uv pip install requests pandas
uv run python script.py

# Create a new Python project with modern structures
uv init my-project2
cd my-project2

uv add requests pandas # Install packages
uv run python script.py # Run Python scripts
Script Execution without creating venv
uv add --script script.py requests pandas
uv run script.py







Official Download: https://nodejs.org/en/download





Podman is a daemonless container engine for developing, managing, and running OCI containers.


Documentation: https://podman.io/docs/installation
# Install Podman
sudo apt install podman -y

# Verify installation
podman --version





# Pull and run Ollama container
podman run -d \
  --name ollama \
  -p 11434:11434 \
  -v ollama_data:/root/.ollama \
  docker.io/ollama/ollama:latest

# Verify Ollama is running
podman ps

# Pull a model (e.g., llama2)
podman exec -it ollama ollama pull llama2

# Test Ollama
curl http://localhost:11434/api/generate -d '{
  "model": "llama2",
  "prompt": "Why is the sky blue?"
}'



# Pull and run PostgreSQL container
podman run -d \
  --name postgres \
  -e POSTGRES_PASSWORD=mysecretpassword \
  -e POSTGRES_USER=admin \
  -e POSTGRES_DB=mydb \
  -p 5432:5432 \
  -v postgres_data:/var/lib/postgresql/data \
  docker.io/library/postgres:16

# Verify PostgreSQL is running
podman ps

# Connect to PostgreSQL
podman exec -it postgres psql -U admin -d mydb



# Pull and run pgAdmin container
podman run -d \
  --name pgadmin \
  -e PGADMIN_DEFAULT_EMAIL=admin@example.com \
  -e PGADMIN_DEFAULT_PASSWORD=admin \
  -p 5050:80 \
  -v pgadmin_data:/var/lib/pgadmin \
  docker.io/dpage/pgadmin4:latest

# Access pgAdmin at: http://localhost:5050
# Login with: admin@example.com / admin






Tip



Connect pgAdmin to PostgreSQL:
- Host: host.containers.internal (or your machineâ€™s IP)
- Port: 5432
- Username: admin
- Password: mysecretpassword








KVM (Kernel-based Virtual Machine) is a Type-1 hypervisor for Linux that allows you to run virtual machines.


# Install KVM and related tools
sudo apt install qemu-kvm libvirt-daemon-system libvirt-clients bridge-utils virt-manager -y

# Enable and start libvirt service
sudo systemctl enable libvirtd
sudo systemctl start libvirtd

# Add your user to libvirt and kvm groups
sudo usermod -aG libvirt,kvm $USER

# Apply group changes (logout/login or restart)
newgrp libvirt






Warning



Important: You need to logout and login (or restart) for group changes to take effect.





# Check if KVM is available
kvm-ok

# Check libvirt status
sudo systemctl status libvirtd

# Verify your user is in the correct groups
groups



# Launch Virtual Machine Manager
virt-manager

- Podman commands are compatible with Docker (alias docker=podman works)

Answer:
- KVM is a Type-1 hypervisor (runs directly on hardware), VirtualBox is Type-2 (runs on host OS)
- KVM has better performance (near-native speed)
- KVM is built into the Linux kernel
- VirtualBox is easier to use with a better GUI
- KVM is better for production/server use
- VirtualBox is better for desktop/development use on multiple OS



Answer:
- Containers share the host OS kernel, VMs have their own complete OS
- Containers are lightweight (MBs), VMs are heavy (GBs)
- Containers start in seconds, VMs take minutes
- Containers have lower overhead and better performance
- VMs provide stronger isolation and can run different OS types
- Containers are ideal for microservices, VMs for running different operating systems



Answer:
- Isolation - Each tool runs in its own container, no conflicts
- Portability - Same environment across different machines
- Easy cleanup - Remove containers without affecting your system
- Version management - Run multiple versions of the same tool
- No system pollution - Keep your host system clean
- Reproducibility - Share exact configurations with team members
